Calling her a woman seems funny now, as funny as the thought that we were contemplating marriage while we were still both children.
I'm sure she is as thankful as I am that we didn't go through with it.
As I played, she was standing in the doorway at the far end of the room.
She was crying.
It had nothing to do with the quality of my performance.
I was not good enough, or bad enough, to move anyone to tears.
It was Scott Joplin who made her cry because this piece, ""Solace,"" provides anything but.
It will dislodge any repressed pain and force it from your body, through your tear ducts when necessary.
This piece had been with us for years and it was reminding us then of the good times and making it clear once and for all that they would not be coming back.
